responses.content: Our approach has always been about this distributed computing fabric, viewing hybrid not as a transitory phase but as a long-term vision for how computing will meet real-world needs. Compute will migrate to wherever data is generated, increasingly at the edge. Hybrid benefits are driving Azure choices, and we're gaining market share with our competitive data center products. Architecturally, we feel well-positioned, as discussed at our Ignite conference, to support our customers' distributed computing needs.

We are in gaming because we believe in the secular changes in the gaming market. Our structural position allows any endpoint to be a great platform for high-end games. With our business model that includes Game Pass and game streaming, we leverage our cloud infrastructure to enhance gaming experiences. The synergy between gaming and the rest of our business is significant, as the same Azure infrastructure supports gaming, Microsoft 365, Dynamics 365, and LinkedIn. This integration allows us to optimize our resources and drive innovation across all platforms.

responses.topic: Microsoft Teams Adoption and Value Proposition
responses.content: Teams has had an explosive breakout year, surpassing previous platform effects like SharePoint. It serves as a comprehensive tool for communications, collaboration, and business processes. Teams is not limited to knowledge workers; it also provides significant value to first-line workers in various industries. The integration of security, compliance, and governance with Teams makes it a preferred choice for enterprise customers, enhancing their productivity and reducing security risks.

responses.topic: Azure Hybrid Benefit and Revenue Impact
responses.content: The Azure Hybrid Benefit offers flexibility for customers adopting hybrid computing models, supporting both lift-and-shift and modern cloud-native applications. This benefit enhances our business model by aligning with customer needs for operational sovereignty and compliance. As customers utilize these hybrid benefits, the revenue impact transitions from on-premises KPIs to Azure consumption, reflecting our integrated cloud strategy.

responses.topic: Intelligent Cloud Business and Hybrid Perspective
responses.content: Our commercial bookings growth has reached unprecedented levels on a constant currency basis, driven by larger, long-term Azure contracts. This growth is not concentrated among a few customers but is part of a broad-based trend across various industries, including those traditionally slow to adopt the cloud. The shift towards strategic partnerships and digital transformation initiatives with our customers contributes to this sustained and diversified growth.

responses.topic: Azure Gross Margins and Cost Structure
responses.content: Azure gross margins have continued to improve through software and hardware innovations, supply chain optimizations, and increased usage of premium services. The ratio of fixed versus variable costs remains relatively stable, with depreciation and fixed costs accounting for approximately 40%. While there is still room for margin improvement, our focus on efficiency and premium workload adoption supports ongoing gross margin expansion.

The durability of our Server & Tools growth is supported by sustainable trends such as our hybrid value proposition and premium mix. While there was a pull-forward of demand due to SQL Server and Windows Server expirations, the underlying drivers like hybrid licensing and premium services ensure that the growth remains robust over time. This durability is reflected in our continued investment in infrastructure and our ability to meet customer needs effectively.

Our commercial cloud gross margin improvement is driven by faster revenue growth compared to capital expenditure growth, structural improvements in cost per unit, and a shift towards premium services. This includes selling more SaaS-like services and consumption-based services that offer higher margins. Our five-year roadmap for gross margin improvement is on track, with Azure gross margins continuing to benefit from these factors.

responses.topic: Windows OEM Revenue and Migration Tailwind
responses.content: On the OEM side, we anticipate continued low inventory levels due to ongoing chip supply constraints, which should sustain our Windows OEM revenue performance. The tailwind from the Win7/Win10 migration is expected to extend for a few more quarters, particularly as small and medium businesses continue their transitions. In the volume licensing and commercial segments, we see double-digit billings and strong demand driven by our Microsoft 365 value proposition.

Dynamics 365 has grown to over $2 billion, surpassing our on-premises business. This growth is driven by our modular and modern business process applications, AI-first modules, and a disruptive business model that enhances competitiveness. The integration of AI and the development of new business applications without direct competition further accelerate Dynamics 365's growth. We continue to see significant opportunities in business process automation, positioning Dynamics 365 for sustained expansion.

Commercial cloud gross margins have improved by 200 basis points sequentially and 600 basis points year-over-year to 65%. This improvement is sustainable due to ongoing structural improvements, cost per unit reductions, and a shift towards higher-margin premium services. As Azure continues to grow and consumption-based services expand, we expect gross margins to continue improving, although the rate of improvement may moderate as revenue mixes shift.

questions: For Satya, can you talk about how hybrid engagements are rolling out with larger customers, how they're contracting, and how they engage both on-premise and cloud assets, especially in driving Server & Tools? For Amy, with Server & Tools up 14% in constant currency, how durable is this growth considering pull-forward demand from SQL Server and Windows Server expirations versus what is sustainable over time?

Amy, regarding the material improvements in Azure gross margins that have benefited commercial cloud gross margin, how much of this improvement is due to lower data center expansion rates and reduced depreciation/amortization, and how much is from better capacity utilization? Additionally, are you ratcheting up your target gross margins for Azure?

Amy, with the strong performance in Windows OEM Pro and volume licensing, how much tailwind is left from the Win7/Win10 migration? Is it reasonable to expect only two quarters of this tailwind? Additionally, can the volume licensing or commercial and cloud services segment contribute to double-digit growth in Fiscal '20?

Satya, can you provide more color on how the gaming business fits into Microsoft's overall direction for the next few years, including any changes in synergy with the rest of the business? Amy, regarding the AI investment driving Intelligent Cloud op-ex growth, how do you see Microsoft progressing on the AI journey and is AI already driving significant revenue for Azure?

Amy, with commercial cloud gross margins increasing by 200 basis points sequentially and 600 basis points year-over-year to 65%, how sustainable are these cloud gross margins at the $40-billion-plus scale? Were there any one-time benefits that contributed to this quarter's performance?

Satya, regarding Microsoft Teams, why are customers adopting it, especially larger ones? Is it due to it being a single app with combined features, or part of the broader Office experience? Amy, how critical is Teams to the long-term price migration for Office and Microsoft 365, considering E1, E3, E5, and associated add-ons like calling?

Satya, with 180 million users now on Office 365 Commercial, how far along are you in the adoption cycle, and is there still significant opportunity for seat expansion in the upcoming year? Amy, given strong uptake of premium SKUs and seat count growth driven by frontline workers, how much opportunity remains on the traditional seat migration front versus leaning more on frontline workers to sustain growth? Is there a point where seat growth and frontline workers could start to limit your ability to continue lifting ARPU on your existing base?

Satya, regarding Dynamics, it's now at $2 billion and growing organically at a pace not matched by many others, surpassing the on-premises business. What are the drivers behind this growth, and how did you achieve this scale? What are the key drivers moving forward?
